headline: Panel looking into D.C. riot adds tactics
author: The New York Times
sentences: Four of the panel's most sought-after witnesses -- conservative lawyer John Eastman; Jeffrey Clark, a Justice Department lawyer deeply involved in Trump's attempts to try to stay in power; conspiracy theorist Alex Jones; and longtime Trump adviser Roger Stone -- invoked the Fifth Amendment as a way to avoid answering questions without the threat of a contempt of Congress charge.

"Having lived through and being a part of every major congressional investigation over the past 50 years, from Iran-Contra to Whitewater to everything else, this is the mother of all investigations and a quantum leap for Congress in a way I've never seen before," said Stanley Brand, a Democrat and the former top lawyer for the House.

Faced with at least 16 Trump allies who have signaled that they will not fully cooperate with the committee, investigators have taken a page out of organized crime prosecutions and quietly turned at least six lower-level Trump staff members into witnesses who have provided information about their bosses' activities, sources say.

As the House investigation was gaining momentum late last year, the committee's vice chairperson, Rep. Liz Cheney, R-Wyo., read from the criminal code to describe a law that she believed could be used to prosecute Trump for obstructing Congress as it sought to certify the Electoral College count of his defeat.

In an attempt to hold Trump and his team accountable, the committee -- which has no authority to pursue criminal charges -- is seen as using what powers it has in expansive ways in hopes of pressuring Attorney General Merrick Garland to use the Justice Department to investigate and potentially prosecute.

The House select committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection at the U.S. Capitol is borrowing techniques from federal prosecutions, employing tactics typically used against mobsters and terrorists as it seeks to break through stonewalling from former President Donald Trump and his allies.

Trump's allies have criticized not just the aggressiveness of the committee but also the expansive list of people questioned, some of whom, the allies maintain, had minimal or no involvement in the events of Jan. 6.

Three Republican members of Congress -- Rep. Kevin McCarthy of California, the House minority leader; Rep. Scott Perry of Pennsylvania; and Jordan -- told the committee that they would refuse to sit for questioning.

The committee has no law enforcement role, and its stated goal is to write a comprehensive report and propose recommendations, including for legislation, to try to make sure the events of Jan. 6 are never repeated.
